critique: This executive order delegates authority related to the Communications Act of 1934 to the Director of the Office of Defense Mobilization during times of war or a declared state of war. It does not touch on immigration, economic regulation, or social inclusion. It could be seen as expanding executive power during emergencies, and potentially impacting civil liberties in favor of national security during such times. It also centralizes power at the federal level. There's no clear ideological tilt based on the text alone.
